TL:DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:Max Payne 2: Fall of Max Payne is the sequel to the critically acclaimed and award winning 2001 game, Max Payne. Max Payne 2 is a Third-Person action shooter developed by Remedy Entertainment which was acquired by Rockstar Games whose notable works include the popular Grand Theft Auto (GTA) franchise.Once again the player steps into the shoes of Max Payne, a New York City Detective who, after the events of the first game, went on a downward spiral both in career and personal life, struggling with the death of his family and his newly formed Pain Killer addiction (the direct result of the pain killers taken by the player in the first game to regenerate lost health). While Max is investigating a series of murders and assassinations, Max encounters Mona Sax, a textbook femme fatale who was presumed dead from the first game. Follow Max and Mona's adventure through New York City and discover a conspiracy behind a Mob War between two rival Mafia groups and a deadly team of hitmen called 'The Cleaners' in this film noir love story.PROS:+ Significant and highly noticeable improvements on the graphics, animation and texture quality from the first title+ Better sounds, voice acting and sound track+ Improvements on the innovative Bullet Time game mechanic+ Great locations and level design which goes well with the better graphical fidelity+ Graphic Novel style cutscenes are back and with better delivery+ Expanded weapon variety+ Mission variety+ Challenging Difficulty levels (the game provides a good challenge on any difficulty setting)+ Adaptive difficulty if the player is on Easy Mode. (AI gets toned down and pain killers heal more if the player dies too much on Easy Mode.)+ Magnificent story that surpasses even the first game+ World is ALIVE and more immersive.CONS:- VERY Short (I personally completed it within 5-6 hours)OTHER NOTE:- Replayability: - Linear storytelling is FINE, its a good way to tell a narrative story in a directed pace but Linearity does sacrifice replayability at degree because, after finishing the story, there is little reason to play through it a second time around. Like a good action movie, it's best to be played again after some time has passed. (Copy Pasted from my Max Payne 1 Review)CONCLUSION:I rarely call something a 'MASTERPIECE' but after playing through the whole game, twice (once on my Xbox back in 2005, once again on my PC 2013), and sitting here writing this review, I cannot find any more CONs aside from the short story. Contrast this to the PROS I listed, I can easily say we have an almost perfect action game. Max Payne 2 blends perfectly the immersive storytelling of a good action movie, and the dynamic adrenaline pumping gameplay of a video game.MUST BUY and HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for both new and old fans a like. I do, however, not recommend you buy this game solo but instead, BUY the MAX PAYNE BUNDLE which includes the Original Max Payne and Max Payne 2. At $15, this is a game worth your time and money.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? Posted: August 22, 2015
												Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is a direct sequel to Remedy Entertainment's critically acclaimed 2001 third-person shooter Max Payne and picks up after the events of its predecessor. The game could be best described as noir-style love story, in contrast to the first that was more of a film noir revenge tale.NYPD detective Max Payne is once again the primary protagonist, although a few very interesting segments sees you play as his love interest, Mona Sax. Max Payne 2 borrows a lot from the original and there are enough hints and references to the previous game which helps keep the narrative interesting and fresh for old-timers.Max Payne 2 is, in many ways, a huge improvement over Max Payne 1. Gone is that constipated look  replaced instead with full 3-D modeled faces. The game also sees an immense graphical upgrade with excellent usage of the Havok 2.0 physics engine. Game characters are more detailed while environment objects, including enemies, tumble and fall very realistically.Gameplay is largely the same with a few refinements to combat. Bullet Time sees an upgrade allowing you to dodge bullets and reload quickly, with a cool whirling animation to go alongside it. This results in a higher body count but also makes gun-play segments a whole lot less challenging. Level designs are, once again, brilliant with mission locales ranging from warehouses, mansions, hospitals and clubs to constructions sites. And the enemy AI is, on a whole, pretty decent although in a few instances they end up killing themselves with their own grenade. The plot is riveting with almost non-stop action throughout. The storyline unfolds in much the same fashion as the original. The usage of graphic novel comics complete with melodramatic over-the-top dialogue sucks you into the game's environment. If anything, the writing is more polished this time around with lots of witty and philosophical quotes thrown into the mix. The story focuses too much upon the love-story angle though which tends to get a bit jarring towards the end. In comparison, the original Max Payne's story, although slightly rough around the edges, was more dark, grittier and compelling than its sequel. For a game that is over twelve years old, Max Payne 2 still holds remarkably well today. It overshadows the original in many aspects while also introducing a few cool mechanics of its own. Simplified mechanics make for interesting combat segments making Max Payne 2 one of the very best third-person shooters ever made.

												One of the most interesting aspects of Max Payne 2 was how much it expanded upon MP1, but also how different a game it was in general.While both games borrow from old detective stories and graphic novels. Max Payne 2 is moreso inspired by romance stories. The main character is portrayed far more realistically, as a depressed lonely individual who has gotten everything he wanted at the end of the last game. And then a girl from his past re-enters his life and thrusts him on another adventure into the night. I wouldn't say the story was perfect, it is a little short and doesn't have the same mythological basis as the first. But it does it's job and I respect Remedy for attempting to do something different.The gameplay was greatly improved, with a true physics engine and reworked AI. The maps were also made a lot larger and the action a lot more upscale. With friendly AI and a survival mode referred to as "Dead Man Walking". Max Payne 2 was a great way to finish Remedy's involvement with the franchise, and is truly a smashing successor to the original.

												Where do I begin? Max Payne 2 The Fall of Max Payne is a fantastic experience from start to end. Especially if you have the Cinema 2.0 Mod which I used in my playthrough of the game. (The Mod really enhances the experience). Storywise this game is interesting, compelling, and tells a dark tale of Max Payne. It's fun, fast, and can be difficult at times (Except in the last chapter where there is practically painkillers around every damn corner) and Bullet Time is a fantastic feature which allows you to slow down time and shoot in slow-mo just like in an action movie (You can even dodge and jump forward in Slow-Mo). There is also a lot of guns (Even a Minigun) but you lose them in certian chapters and have to collect them again. You do all of this in Third Person which makes it even cooler seen Max dodge bullets and shoot punks.Graphics still hold up today. This game looks great and very little loading screens (only when you get to a new chapter) and character models looks great. It's not any Next-Gen Graphics but it's great vanilla and looks even better with Graphical Mods you can download.Do I recommend this game? Yes. It's a great game.Should you buy it right now or wait for a sale? content:
Posted: February 21
“Like all the bad things in my life,it started with the death of a woman.”Criminally underrated and an often unrecognised milestone for the third-person shooter and gaming as a whole, Max Payne was quite the contrast to everything that had preceded it. While gritty and dark level design was apparent in the likes of Quake, Fallout and Thief, the concept of film noir had yet to be truly tested within the format of a video game. During a time in which the first-person shooter reigned supreme and the so-called “golden age” neared its end, a small Finnish studio decided to try something bold and new.Enter Remedy Entertainment and the landmark that is Max Payne.Armed with a turned-up leather jacket, a weapon in each hand and a tonne of pills, you return as everyone’s favourite anti-hero detective and are unleashed once again upon the filthy underbelly of New York City. Caught within the throes of a rapidly deteriorating gang war and still gripped by grief of his young family’s death, your journey to break the cycle of crime will only lead Max further into the darkness and confrontation he has tried to avoid for so long. As both friend and foe make their play from the shadows and the stakes continue to be raised however, how far you are willing to push both the man and the city towards redemption is no longer for you to decide. Prepare for unforeseen consequences.  Best described as the equivalent of AC/DC’s Hells Bells, the core gameplay of the Max Payne series is some of the best yet seen in a shooter and, without a doubt, as stylish as the influences it wears so well. From leaping through the air with specks of debris trailing in your path as you clear out a room of enemies, to running and gunning your way through an entire building of psyched-up addicts, ‘satisfying’ doesn’t even begin to capture how incredible the mayhem is to experience. John Woo would be proud.With their only prior release in the form of a charming little DOS-based racer called Death Rally, the low-budget origins of Remedy’s classic continues to demonstrate just how inspired and creative a small team can be. Depicting such a dreary and seemingly hopeless world that often veers from poetic self-reflection to the downright comical is a testament to the love put into crafting the world and the developer’s skill as a whole.The series’ iconic cutscenes, (once home to Remedy’s friends and even Sam Lake himself), have taken more of a backseat this time around, favouring in-game rendering for most of the set pieces on offer. Admittedly, the transition between the two can be more jarring than usual when the graphic novel style is forced to cover through implication what the engine is unable to handle, but visually the game has held up admirably after all these years. Thanks to the higher production value, MP2 certainly isn’t bland and being transported into the depths of a dream sequence and Max’s tortured mind will quickly remind you of this, if the brilliantly moody soundtrack and fluid animation hasn't done so already.“Max, we gotta stop meeting like this.”Alongside the character of the city itself, Mona Sax is definitely the standout, with her well established femme fatale dynamic with Max carrying over from the first game. The excellent performances by Timothy Gibbs, Kathy Tong, James McCaffrey and Wendy Hoopes respectively deliver the top-notch voice acting alongside the equally stellar cast of both the new and returning characters. (Who could forget  or Lords and Ladies?)As one of the most fascinating and tragic relationships in gaming, the ultimately fatal attraction between the two characters is incredibly well-written, with such nuance stealing the show. Here’s looking at you, kid.The few complaints that I could make generally come down to uneven difficulty and some hilarious physics moments, but these are mostly negligible. The changes to bullet time might be considered sacrilege by some, but electing for a more fast-paced than methodical approach hasn't hurt combat in the slightest, with the sheer power of the many weapons on offer providing some of the best action of its time. MP2 is still quite short, but the clear and concise direction that it takes throughout redeems the amount of hours, particularly if you throw in some mods or a 'Dead on Arrival' run too. “I had a dream of my wife. She was dead. But it was all right.”Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is a remarkable achievement in nearly all aspects of its design and a worthy follow-up to the original, even more so when compared to the countless pale imitations or lifeless big budget titles that have emerged since. As masters of their craft, Remedy have more than fulfilled the series' goal of translating film noir alongside the impressive technical action and produced an enduring icon of the gaming industry.While not exactly a “joy” to experience, wake yourself up from the American Dream and embrace one of the best third-person shooters ever made. Thumbs up.

												Max Payne 2 came out eleven years ago so it seems odd to do a review of it. I'm sure that not exactly very many of you are going to be swayed to buy the game or anything like that. Yet I still want to recommend an absolutely fantastic mod that caught my eye for the game and I have been playing through. Payne Evolution takes a classic game and makes it even better by refining it with some of the features and improvements of Max Payne 3. Every gun is replaced by a new variant from Max Payne 3, new dialogue is is introduced when Max picks up painkillers ("I was self-medicating, like a good American") and the MP3 bullet time effects are introduced. New sounds are added for so many things, of especially good quality being the new weapon sound effects. It really is a wholesale improvement on what was already an amazing game. Here is a link to the mod: http://www.moddb.com/mods/payne-evolutionI was surprised by just how much fun I had with the classic film-noir love story. The game holds up really well too in terms of aging. The revolutionary at the time physics and environmental interactivity is still really impressive. The level design is something else (it's really refreshing to have this big wide open level design to explore, in stark comparison to the heavily scripted nature of modern games) and the characterisation is strong. Like Max, you find yourself falling in love with Mona and hating Vlad just as much as he does. The dialogue is top-notch, with Max's brooding and dark outlook on life feeling a lot more original and fleshed out than Max Payne 3's lines. The comic book style presentation feels really unique too, a fine example of not so heavy-handed storytelling. The game at times made me miss some of the traits I associate with games in the days of yore, truth be told. The original game's excellence is further enhanced with the the brilliance of the Payne Evolution mod. Hell, if anything can vindicate that then probably the best moment is when the mod maker took inspiration (well, blatantly copied really) the song for for the final sequence of Max Payne 3, which is incredibly haunting and well fitting, and added it to the final sequence of Max Payne 2. If anything, it fits even better.

												Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is an action story driven game, created by Remedy Entertainment (Creators of Quantum Break and Alan Wake) and published by Rockstar Games. This game has a serious, dark noire and comic strip storyline feel which is the strongest aspect about Max Payne franchise, it's similar concept to Watchmen movie. The game sets after the predecessor's (Max Payne) timeline, causing Max Payne became a hard-boiled criminal. The graphics has been outdated in today's standards. The gameplay seems to be unique back in the day. Max Payne's franchise are known for a signature mechanic, "Bullet Time". Bullet time slows down time and pick off all targets with ease. There are some technical flaws about this game, the platform level design is frustrating me because I tried to jump from gap to gap and the character jumps vertically than leaping it but thank god you can use the dive animation to get another ledge. They don't have sort of objective marker because I don't know where I am supposed to go, so I have to back track the route once I have a key or easily get lost.+ Pros+ Dark, intriguing and plot-twist storyline with comic strip and noire feel+ Characters are interesting with excellent voice acting+ Bullet time+ Checkpoints or manual save system are generous+ More arsenals to kill with- Cons- Latest DirectX drivers are not supported.- Easy to get lost when trying to find a path, so backtrack is recommended like I do- Graphics are outdated in today's standardsFor this game's review, I recommend this game if you want to try it or one of those gamers who loves storytelling like myself. This is one of my favourite franchise to play because of the storyline and the bullet time. But I was really sad that this game is no longer supported with later DirectX drivers. This game doesn't disappoint outside technical issues. The final score is 9 out of 10, a solid recommendation.

Max Payne 2: The Fall Of Max Payne			* 8/10A direct sequel for the tragedy of Max Payne.Back as a cop once again thanks to Senator Alfred Woden's influence, Max is following a case about a criminal gang disguised as cleaners. This new epsode will take us to old places, old friends and will uncover some dirty secrets. Gameplay follows the first max payne, a 3rd person view action with bullet time, and the story is told by Max with comic pages, as already happened before. One again the game is divided in 3 acts with chapters preceded by some prologue dream sessions.The dark noir atmosphere is always strong, with urban ambiences, old known locations such as the RagnaRock, and other new locations. Now levels are more articulated, details rich and filled with Sam Lake... I mean side stories disguised as Sam La... I mean, TV series. This might sound dumb or useless, but creating a world in a world helps in making it more real and credible.The engine is an improved and updated version of Max Payne's MaxFX, so now, besides a general graphic update, we can have real 3d face expressions in place of the old 2d flat faces. Too bad they're way less expressive now. Now the story isn't being told with comics alone but there are more scenes in-game, especially action scenes rendered and studied with a great direction as usual.Truth be told everything in this chapter is well done and studied, the story, plot twists, engine and gameplay. The problem is it doesn't innovate much the game as much as expected, as we'll mostly see characters and places from the previous title, and facts in the story will essentially be the same, or follow the same structure established in the first title. The only innovation lies in the fact we won't be playing as Max in a bunch of chapters, where we'll move a characters moving along with Max and catching up with him.Considering the age of this game it might give some minor troubles when you launch it, mainly incompatibilities with modern OSs (Such as Windows 10), which can be easily solved with compatibility mode. Another issue could be with integrated GPUs, it recognized my laptop's intel GPU but not my nVidia GPU. Luckily my Intel GPU was performing enough to handle MP2 maxed out at 90 FPS or more, so I didn't even had to try to force it to run with my nVidia.+++PROs+++ SEQUEL. A sequel of the first game worth its title, with the same good aspects such as bullet time, good plot, comics, updated engine and a great direction for cutscenes.---CONs--- SEQUEL. Unfortunately this sequel brings quality without innovation as gameplay and even the story, despite being well written and with plot twists, seems like a repeated formula from the first title. MINOR COMPATIBILITY ISSUES. The age of the game brings some minor compatibility issues such as forced windowed game, or unrecognized GPUs. Luckily none of them represent a serious issue and can be easily solved to play smoothly.I played this game on this machine:Laptop Lenovo Z50Intel Core i5-4210U8Gb RAM DDR3GeForce 840MIntel HD Graphics 4400Windows 10 Home x64

Posted: March 6
"When entertainment turns into a surreal reflection of your life, you're a lucky man if you can laugh at the joke. Luck and I weren't on speaking terms." - Max Payne Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne - a noir love story.The ingredients list, the texture, the flavour, even the ending. What you get couldn't be more written on the tin if it tried. Which is both its selling point and its main detractor. As a game, it's excellent. The pacing is seamless, the mechanics responsive, the direction flawless. Where the first game gave you a tenuous dripfeed of bullettime, the sequel drowns you in it - each encounter usually ending in an invincible assault on wolves rendered sitting ducks as the sands of time become a suggestion and not a command - where even the default pistols quickly down the single enemy type, putting enough bullets in brains to say you're sharpening lead.On top of the quickly-recharging "I Win" meter, you have your spammable bullet-time dodge that doesn't use meter, but is balanced by the recovery frames meaning that you will die using it. It doesn't get used often.Weapons themselves are bog-standard. Pistols, rifles, shotguns, just about everything you could expect. It's never in danger of getting too inventive. A trait that plagues the game. The noir love story is fine, it's okay, it drives the game. But this was the sequel to Max Payne, the meta-deconstruction deliberate trainwreck that balanced insanity with quotable lines. Just about everything memorable about Max Payne 2's setting, details and dialogue is a direct reference to the permanent constipated grimace writing of the first game. It brings its own comparatively muted flavour to the table - you have optional TV shows that parody the game itself, along with a slurry of easter eggs and interactable objects. But every vestige of interest is shunted to the side like an unwanted child, a quality applicable to much of The Fall of Max Payne."As surely as the bullet rips through the victim's flesh, organ and bone, it shatters the image of the man who presses the trigger." - Max Payne The OST is fantastic, but only spikes up when it feels like it and tends to feel totally out of place, a trippy mix of tunes blasting while you're idly checking dead bodies for painkillers. The periods of calm between the firefights, where you're just wandering around interacting with stuff, don't wear out their welcome (especially compared to some of these recent games that slow you down to a crawl to compensate for that being their sole gameplay) but honestly there's not enough of them compared to the samey-looking construction rooms full of goons they're happy to throw at you.On the flipside, there's no real bossfights either. The one at the end is a physics puzzle. Combine the two and you have a game where neither the climactic moments nor the downtime manage to satisfy.There's a couple of points that are straight improvement over the first game. Especially in regards to compatibility - these days, Max Payne 1 is a bit of a chore to get running. Max Payne 2 looks better, runs better, and works straight out of the box. It's even compatible with the Steam Overlay, you don't see that often with games from the same era. Even difficulty-wise it's an absolute improvement - while the first game was all about abusing the coded accuracy drop while roll-strafing, the sequel lets you handle enemies with a whole lot more grace and style.Even if it does tend to come down to "whoever lands a shot first wins". Get used to savescumming if your reflexes are as bad as mine.Max Payne 2 is a great game worth playing. A noir love story that rides on the adrenaline-bloodlines of New York. Even if it does lose quite a bit of the magic from the first."I had a dream of my wife.She was dead.But it was alright."

My Personal Score: 3/5PCGamingWiki Page[pcgamingwiki.com]Issues: none experienced during playthroughsMax Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne improves on everything which made the first game great and even surpasses it in some aspects. The gameplay isn't as awkward as before thanks to improved hitboxes and bullet trajectories, a sense of realism surrounds the game because of physics simulations like ragdoll effects, and the identity of the series has been given a new facelift thanks to higher production values. Overall, an excellent action game that's worthy of the Max Payne name and fans will be happy with this installment. However, if you're new to the series or have only played the Rockstar-made entry, you won't get as much from this game and everything will just look like a confusing mess. Max Payne 2 is a story-centric game and it builds on what fans and players of the first game already knows. This time around, the true intentions of the first game's major players are shown and reveals a new side to them, making them more believable rather than being a one-sided cliche of a character. The story focuses on Max after the events of the first title as he reflects on his past choices and how he copes up with the decisions that he's made. I highly suggest that new players play the first game or watch a recap video because without knowledge of the characters' background and the events leading up to this game, the story becomes much less impactful and you won't get much out of it because of its focus on the cast rather than plot.Improvements that I've noticed:1. Better voice actors than the first game and their performances are consistent except for some select moments.2. The new soundtrack is great, especially "Late Goodbye" by Poets of The Fall which is featured prominently in the game.3. Still linear but bigger levels with the inclusion of optional explorable rooms make it seem less so.4. Very serious story with comedic undertones. Sam Lake and Remedy somehow managed to make the virtual enemies that you're killing appear human in nature rather than just fodder that blocks your way. They laugh, they share jokes and share experiences with their friends, they also play the piano real good - very small details delivered in a very funny way but it still makes a lot of difference for the personal story that they're presenting to the player.And there you have it.

Posted: October 27, 2015
												"The Fall of Max Payne". Funny, I don't remember there ever being a "Rise of Max Payne". These games are about a man who lost everything, there was never a rise...was there? Sometime in-between completing Max Payne 1 and the sequel, I finally watched John Woo's The Killer. While a classic in its own right due to the intense shoot-outs, I was especially impressed by its usage of tragedy. Ah Jong is an assassin, but he has morals and a sense of honor. Early on in the film, he accidentally blinds Jennie - a nightclub singer - during a hired hit. Thus, he takes on one last job. The reward would be used for Jennie's vision-saving operation. However, Jong is betrayed by his superiors. (SPOILERS)Over the course of the movie, Ah Jong befriends and eventually partners with Inspector Li Ying. Before the climatic battle, Jong asks Ying to promise that if/when he dies, his corneas be used to save Jennie's eyesight. So even if worst came to worst, Jennie could hopefully return to a normal life.  Unfortunately, in the last minutes of the movie, he's shot in the eyes by the villain. Before Jong succumbs to his wounds, he can hear Jennie's cries. Due to their blindness, neither of them can find one another, despite being just a few feet apart. Not only does Jong die, but his noble sacrifice is denied. Everything he worked (and killed) for over the course of the movie was for naught. Although Ying survives, he has lost good friends, and becomes disillusioned with the concept of justice. Shortly after starting a new game in Max Payne 1, you're treated to the horrifying deaths of Max's wife and child. As time passes, he is framed for murder, wipes out half the criminal underworld, and develops an addiction to painkillers. However, if you've played through the game, then you can recall the final lines: "Woden grinned smugly. It was the grin of a winner. That made two of us." Max Payne is a winner. He succeeded in his mission of vengeance. For us, the audience, that's a satisfying end. So in its own way, Max Payne 1 chronicled the rise, so now we must witness the fall. Tragedy isn't just when a person dies, it's also when their hopes, dreams, and emotions are extinguished.All that said, there is a lot of joy to be found in Max Payne 2. It's a twisted game, one that isn't afraid to poke fun at itself. This sense of humor keeps the game from coming off as overly dour. It feels especially rewarding to fans of the first title, because they'll pick up on all of the references. It's the kind of humor that fits the tone of the story. It's dark and depressing, but it also has a very distinct noir quality to it. Everything is interconnected, and you get the sense that Max might just be a small part of a much larger story. The "TV shows" that can be seen in various points of the game are a reflection of this. MP2 is a little shorter than its predecessor, but there's more imagery to absorb in every scene.As for the actual videogame, I believe the combat mechanics are a marked improvement over the first entry. The concept hasn't changed much. You run through every level shooting all of the bad guys. Where this game differs is it showcases a bit more nuance, and a higher level of confidence. One of the first notable changes is that Max takes less damage. This brings it more in-line with the John Woo movies, where good guys shrug off bullets. A couple shot-gun blasts are still usually enough to bring Max from very healthy to dead, but occasional stray shots don't take large chunks of life either. This change gives Remedy a little more freedom when designing encounters. They're more involved, and there tends to be more memorable situations. Max Payne 1 was compelling enough even when combat was just "room full of thugs". The sequel changes things up, and it works very well. I don't even hate the escort missions, well...maybe I still hate them a little. These sections run parallel with some interesting and amusing ideas, so I guess I'll let them slide.While I'm not sure if I can attribute this to experience with the prequel, or actual changes, the "bullet-time" system also feels substantially better. When Max slows everything down, his heightened reflexes really come into their own. It's really fun running into an area, triggering the bullet-time, and wasting everyone. The first enemy is still flying through the air from Max's shotgun blast as he kills two more men in rapid succession. Occurences such as this are always welcome. Max also pulls off some sweet reloads while in bullet-time. One other minor but welcome change is that when diving and shooting, Max can continue firing while lying on the ground, until his clip is empty. This game uses Havok physics, but the enemies are properly weighted. This makes it so that kills carry some semblance of realism to them, but the few times where enemies soar, or get knocked around in massive explosions, are still very amusing.On the surface, MP2 comes off as the easier game, but it's balanced out by more thoughtful encounters and harrowing situations. There's a bit more creativity to throw around, and hopefully it keeps players from hitting F5/F9 so much (no guarantees though). Unlike the first game, there is a distinct lack of "boss enemies" aka "thugs who take a lot more bullets to kill". I consider this another positive. Also, just when you really think you've got it down, there are still more difficulties and extra modes to explore. Don't forget to look for the minor details, like people complaining when you stand in-front of them, while they're trying to watch TV.Basically, if you played through the first Max Payne, you're required to check out the sequel. It's a phenomenal game, and features some of the best third-person shooting action around. The story is fantastic as well, and MP2's usage of various interactive elements really sells the "games-as-art" idea. Oh and don't forget the wide-screen fix.

												It was almost morning, waking up from the American Dream. We are willing to suffer, to die for the things we care about. For love, for the right choices, Because of her, I had solved the case. My case. All of it. Story Two years after the events of the previous game, Max Payne is a NYPD detective. Senator Alfred Wooden has kept his promise, and released Max from his history of violence. Max got back to working for the NYPD to keep himself busy in life. After a series of events, Max investigates a group of contract killers called: The Cleaners. Mona Sax, who was presumed dead, is under investigation for killing Senator Gates, a member of "The Inner Circle" from the previous game. The leader of the Russian mob, and Max's old friend Vladimir Lem, finds himself in a heavy mob war with Vinnie Gognitti. Max is determined to find out about the unexpected return from Max's love interest Mona Sax, and who The Cleaners are working for, and what they want. Gameplay Max Payne 2 plays very similar to its first installment. The new and polished bullet-time is back, and better than ever. The animations of the bullet-time just look better, and the bullet-time diving won't lower your stamina bar. The game has like its previous installment 3 parts, each with seven to nine chapters. Next to playing Max, you'll also play as Mona Sax for a few chapters, making the characters bond together even better. There are more guns to choose from, and are in my opinion far more fun to use. Conclusion Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is in my opinion a better game than Max Payne 1. It has one of the best game stories I've ever played, and it takes a few nice twists and turns. The gameplay is amazing and fun to play, and still plays a lot like Max Payne 1. That being said, the only bit of negativity I have for the game, is that it's really short. An average gamer completes the game in six or seven hours. But the story fits perfectly in this time span, nothing needs to be added or left out. But a little bit more time to walk around and shoot is never a bad thing. Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is a phenomenal game, nothing more I can say about it. 9.5/10

═══════════════════════════════════OVERVIEW Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is a third-person action shooter made by Rockstar Games, the developers of Grand Theft Auto, Red Dead Redemption, Bully and many more. You follow the story of Max Payne, a former DEA agent for the New York City Police Department who has trouble keeping up with his life. You will need to fight trough loads of enemies using many available weapons and skills such as slow motion. The game features 3 difficulties; Detective - Enemies and health spawns adapt you, Hard Boiled - Enemies are harder and painkillers spawn rarely, Dead On Arrival - Same as Hard Boiled but with limited saves. There are also 2 bonus difficulties; New York Minute where you need to complete the level as fast as possible and Dead Man Walking where you fight enemies in arena until you die. The game takes around 8 hours to beat depending on what difficulty you took. I really recommend buying this game, you can get it for 2.49€ or for 2.99€ in a great Max Payne 1+2 pack on sale. ═══════════════════════════════════PROS & CONS Pros:Fun | You will want to replay this game sooner or laterAwesome Game Mechanics | Side jumping and slow-mo make this game even better, the fact that you can do things actors do in one of those action movies makes me redo levels just so I can experience that againAddicting Soundtrack | This game has one of the best soundtracks, Main Theme is my personal favorite.Cons:Fullscreen doesn't work on Windows 7 and later | You can fix this by opening task manager, setting it to More Details, using a dropdown arrow on Max Payne process, selecting the process and using option Maximize. If that doesn't work Google is your friend.Confusing Story | I played the game few times and I still can't catch the story which really frustrates me.Dumb AI | NPCs will often fail to do simple tasks or they will just run in gunfire by themselves═══════════════════════════════════SUMMARY & FINAL RATING This game is for everyone that likes action shooters. I rate the game 8/10, would accidentally slow-mo myself from a building again! ═══════════════════════════════════For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow Lot's O Giveaway's group curations here!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2012
												Max Payne 2 The Fall of Max Payne is one of those games that people hate and love. On the one hand you have the multitudes who proclaim that it's noir style is completely groundbreaking and that the storytelling stands in a league of it's own. On the other hand you have the many who say that it's nothing more than hype and that at it's core Max Payne 2 is nothing more than an average shooter enticing the wannabe artsy gamers with a pseudo-deep story and pretty cinematic. You can never tell who's right in an argument like this, both sides will provide equal parts well-thought counterpoints and nonsensical fanatical rantings.Me, I really liked it. Sure the story is not as great as some proclaim but it's not the giant pile of lice infested feces that others call it. And yeah it's not 1930's French movie either but lets be honest, whether you like those kind of movies or not they'd never work as a game, the pacing is completely different.What saves the game for me is the simple fact that the gameplay is nice and solid. The shooting is fast and meaty and the slow motion gimmick that the original Max Payne brought forth to the masses still works well enough that it doesn't bother me as much as it does in other games. Now there is a mechanic that got overused in later games.There is a reason Max Payne is a name many gamers know. Beyond the story, the pretentious artsy cut scenes and all the posturing is some good and solid gameplay, and that's hard to ignore.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2011
Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max PayneI lied to myself that it was over. I was still alive, my loved ones were still dead. It wasn't over.General OverviewFiring a gun is a binary choice. You either pull the trigger or you don't... Max Payne has been taken by the police and is about to face charges for his killing spree. However, he is cleared of all charges, thanks to his relationship with a very influential member of society, Senator Alfred Woden. A few years have passed, and Max has returned to work for the NYPD as a homicide detective. During a routine murder investigation he finds himself face-to-face with the fugitive Mona Sax, a woman he thought was dead. Max and Mona team up to solve the answers to Max's past that left his wife and child dead.My Own ViewsAn incredible leap in gameplay and graphics just 1 year after the release of the first game. The story does not dissapoint. Starting off with the cleaners and finding out Mona is alive (Its not a spoiler its on the game description) dealings with the inner circle and Alfred Woden. Meeting people from the first game, Vladimir Lem & Vinnie Gognitti. Leading up to a massive climax, dark and gritty as in the first.This time the gunplay and bullet time is far superior and you get to play as Mona as well. Certain missions you play both in alternating sequence to get to the goal.James McCaffrey reprises his role as Max and the superb poetic and dark monolougue continues.One other point about this game. It basically introduced the world to Poet's of the fall with their song Late Goodbye. If you like your Scandinavian rock/metal (I do \m/) check these guys out for some lighter rock. Late goodbye can be heard throughout the game from a janitor humming as he cleans, to a cleaner playing it on a grand piano right before (most people blow him up with a grenade) and of course the final credits.One of my favourite PC shooters of all time.Freerider-DaveThe past is a gaping hole. You try to run from it, but the more you run, the deeper, more terrible it grows behind you, its edges yawning at your heels. Your only chance is to turn around and face it. But it's like looking down into the grave of your love. Or kissing the mouth of a gun, a bullet trembling in its dark nest, ready to blow your head off.

												This is one of those kind of rare games that "I keep coming back", one of the key elements of this game is immersion, every level and its attention to detail is amazing, although the level design is most of times a straight line it never gets boring. I think the core of this game is just absorbing every element of the story of this psychology thriller, like a simple tour in a heavy gritty mind of a man. That funhouse level is a perfect example that illustrates this, we simple run through this crazy madhouse fictionally inspired by a fictional tvshow inside the game, these elements try to be realistic in a way that they affect the character and complement the complexity of that fictional Noir York City. I come back to this game not because of the shooting or bullet time but because of the nightmarish feel it always leave me, the characters we interact with always seem crazy, strange and distant. The TVshows always feel like a omen of bad things to come or a satire of Max's life. Technically the physics were pretty good for it's time and the game was released with tools from the developer, something rare nowadays, so there are plenty of mods out there even total conversions. Lots of game interaction, sound design, music, everything, everything in this game was polished and worked. Great game should be preserved! culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												One of the best 3rd person games to have emerged out of the 2000s.  The plot, acting, characters, voice acting and gameplay mechanics are amazing to play even a decade later.The flim noir feel to this game coupled with the hammy lines and gritty New York scene make the plot memorable and enjoyable. The landscapes, sounds, soundtrack, layout and even odd and slightly macabre portraits of the cut outs in the game make for an overally gloomy, moody and atmospheric game. The bullet-time mechanics make this a pleasure to play as you hammer away with your twin deagles in bullet-time mode.What's also really enjoyable are the game's idiosyncrasies: the Lords and Ladies television show that everyone watches with its overly hammy and campy acting; the strung out junkies and hookers who decide to join you only to last several minutes; or the old ladies who toss you a spare shotgun from their living room closet.The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful and haunting with that repeating cello and accompanying orchestra. The first Max Payne introduced the gamer to bullet-time mechanics along with an equally gritty plot copuled with Max's foray into his drug-addled dreamscapes while looking for his family's killers.In the sequel, the graphics have been updated along with a continuation of the plot. I love what Remedy has done with both games. With the third Max Payne, you are granted access to way better graphics, thanks to Rockstar, but frankly the plot paled in comparison with the previous two releases.They don't make games like these anymore...10/10

												It's hard to believe that Max Payne 2 came out over seven years ago. This remains one of the best third person action games ever. The first one was also good but BRUTALLY difficult at points, and Max's hilariously constipated face made for great times, but part 2--pardon the pun--remedies whatever flaws the first one had. Aside from a graphical upgrade, they changed the bullet-time mechanics to basically be Cyborg 009's acceleration mode. As one of the first games to use Havok physics aka "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ physics" in conjunction with ragdoll effects, the gunfights always looked and felt unique.The other great thing about Max Payne 2 that hasn't really been explored since is the ongoing meta-narratives explored by overhearing radio broadcasts and television. A lot of it is referential to the first game, but several of the tales serve as "Shadow Play Girls" / "Tales of the Black Freighter"-esque parallels to existing developments.PS: beat it on Hardest and the ending's a bit different...

												MAX PAYNE 2:A FILM NOIR LOVE STORYOne of the most beautiful, engrossing, atmospheric and entertaining games I've ever had the pleasure of playing.Max Payne 2 is the story of a long and dark night in which the tortured Max Payne struggles to find the answers to the questions he's been asking himself ever since his family was murdered, leaving a stream of bodies and bullets in his wake. content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												 I LOVE THIS GAME.I LOVE THIS GAME.I LOVE THIS GAME.I LOVE THIS GAME.I LOVE THIS GAME.Emg emh.If you saw/read my Max Payne 1 review you'll see that I praised the game for pretty much everything and didn't say much bad about it at all, it's as if the game had no flaws at all and din't need any more improvements.And then Max Payne 2 came a long, also known as THE BEST THIRD PERSON GAME EEEVEEER!!111Everything has been improved, I have said that the soundtrack of MP1 was top-notch, which it was, don't get me wrong, but there was not much of it. Many times in MP1 you'll run around without any music in the background. MP2 not only offers more of it but also its soundtrack pretty much suits any situation perfectly, always. MP2 also changed Max Payne's theme slightly, in my opinion this is the best version of it. The story this time is larger, epic. And its presentation is better than in MP1 if you can even believe that. The comics look much better with professional actors this time around, in MP1 Remedy had to work with what they've got, which I think you've noticed with many goofy looking faces which could be distracting in some parts. Now with bigger budget they have managed to create something truly amazing. Nothing seems weird or odd anymore, Max Payne's smirk also has been removed replaced with a ._. face . I promise you, you will get teary eyed or even cry at the ending. It is that powerful. Meanwhile MP1's story was about revenge, MP2 is about love. MP2 counties to also go deeper into Payne's psyche. Nightmares return and they're not frustrating as before, they are not as creepy, but their presentation is much superior.Throughout the game you can interact with your surroundings, watch TV shows which are still frames, true. But their stories are still strangely engaging or just interesting and it is fun to watch them. You've got♥♥♥♥♥♥Justice for example, a parody of MP1's story and Max Payne's character in general. Lords and Ladies, a parody of soap operas. There are much more of them and they're completely optional.Graphics looks really good, even today you'll have no problem with it, in that case this game has dated much better than the game that came before it. Except good models for the main characters and some good environment graphics all around.Gunplay has been improved; oh it has been improved so much. Just the fact the game has radgolls now! It's so cool! You'll kill a dude and he'll fly away and then and then Max will do this cool spinning thing and the game follows it OH MY GOD IT'S SOO GOOOD!....Let me elaborate.Bullet time and shoot-dodge return and there are slight tweaks to them.Bullet-time now works in a slightly different way, when you start it up the bullet-time it doesn’t seem to slow down as much as it did in the MP1, that is until you kill an enemy. Each time you kill an enemy with Bullet-Time the game slows down more. And when you are forced to reload Max does this spinning move which looks really awesome and doesn't leave you to harm for so long, the move reloads your weapon very quickly. Shoot-dodge has been unchanged for the most part, now the shoot-dodge just doesn't take any bullet time away from you, but you can get harmed and even die while you're performing it. You're no longer invincible as you were in the first game.There are more weapons too and they all feel better to use.The game's difficulty is much more balanced; there are no frustrating cheap deaths which you might have experienced in the first game.When you complete the game you get "Dead Man Walking mode" it's a mode where you are putted into a map from campaign, your quest is to stand and fight as long as you can until you die, you can try to beat your time-limit, it is quite fun and addicting and if you enjoy the gunplay as much as I do it's amazing.The game is on a shorter side, shorter than the first game actually. But does that matter? The game's awesome!11/10, Better than best game ever made, buy it, buy it. Come on, do it.

And its presentation is better than in MP1 if you can even believe that. The comics look much better with professional actors this time around, in MP1 Remedy had to work with what they've got, which I think you've noticed with many goofy looking faces which could be distracting in some parts. Now with bigger budget they have managed to create something truly amazing. Nothing seems weird or odd anymore, Max Payne's smirk also has been removed replaced with a ._. face . I promise you, you will get teary eyed or even cry at the ending. It is that powerful. Meanwhile MP1's story was about revenge, MP2 is about love. MP2 counties to also go deeper into Payne's psyche. Nightmares return and they're not frustrating as before, they are not as creepy, but their presentation is much superior.Throughout the game you can interact with your surroundings, watch TV shows which are still frames, true. But their stories are still strangely engaging or just interesting and it is fun to watch them. You've got♥♥♥♥♥♥Justice for example, a parody of MP1's story and Max Payne's character in general. Lords and Ladies, a parody of soap operas. There are much more of them and they're completely optional.Graphics looks really good, even today you'll have no problem with it, in that case this game has dated much better than the game that came before it. Except good models for the main characters and some good environment graphics all around.Gunplay has been improved; oh it has been improved so much. Just the fact the game has radgolls now! It's so cool! You'll kill a dude and he'll fly away and then and then Max will do this cool spinning thing and the game follows it OH MY GOD IT'S SOO GOOOD!....Let me elaborate.Bullet time and shoot-dodge return and there are slight tweaks to them.Bullet-time now works in a slightly different way, when you start it up the bullet-time it doesn’t seem to slow down as much as it did in the MP1, that is until you kill an enemy. Each time you kill an enemy with Bullet-Time the game slows down more. And when you are forced to reload Max does this spinning move which looks really awesome and doesn't leave you to harm for so long, the move reloads your weapon very quickly. Shoot-dodge has been unchanged for the most part, now the shoot-dodge just doesn't take any bullet time away from you, but you can get harmed and even die while you're performing it. You're no longer invincible as you were in the first game.There are more weapons too and they all feel better to use.The game's difficulty is much more balanced; there are no frustrating cheap deaths which you might have experienced in the first game.When you complete the game you get "Dead Man Walking mode" it's a mode where you are putted into a map from campaign, your quest is to stand and fight as long as you can until you die, you can try to beat your time-limit, it is quite fun and addicting and if you enjoy the gunplay as much as I do it's amazing.The game is on a shorter side, shorter than the first game actually. But does that matter? The game's awesome!11/10, Better than best game ever made, buy it, buy it. Come on, do it.

content:
Posted: February 5
												Max Payne 2 is a direct sequel to the original and picks up after the events of that game. Max, now a detective and wearier than ever of the world, once again has his hands full as he finds himself hopelessly attached to the lovely Mona Sax, a murder suspect and part of a bigger plot that ties in to Max's own dark past. There are tons of references and parallels to the original story. Fans will undoubtedly be pleased by some of the nudging and winking, though someone starting off with Max Payne 2 would probably feel rather left out, despite the presence of an optional cutscene that summarizes what happened leading up to Max Payne 2. Still, this is a surprisingly complex narrative for a game, irrespective of the genre.The storyline unfolds in much the same fashion as the original. It uses some very slick, graphic novel-style storyboards--complete with melodramatic dialogue straight out of a pulp detective novel--and good voice-over to go with it. These graphic novel sequences are unmistakably similar to those of the first game, though they are, in some cases, even more artistic this time around. Max Payne 2 certainly isn't lacking in its presentation. Even the game's special edition DVD-style packaging is slick, and all of the game's between-level loading screens and graphic novel sequences are impressive-looking and often very cool. The plot itself features a number of twists but is rather convoluted the first go-round. Play through the game a second time (perhaps on the higher difficulty setting that's unlocked after you finish it the first time) and you'll likely get a much clearer sense of what's happening.

												Max Payne 2 is amazing. It is a huge improvement over the first Max Payne in nearly every way. One of my favorite, and most important, changes is that Max Payne himself no longer looks like he's smelling a rank fart. He looks like a human. The other characters also look like humans, rather than video game models wearing human faces. The bullet time is infinitely more useful as it replenishes faster and it gets a boost when you kill someone. The dodge-shooting also works better as it will let you keep firing from the ground, and doesn't immediately jump up and break the action until you stop firing.The story is a lot more cohesive, and more interesting. It's not just a dude killing everyone in his way to get to the person who killed his wife and daughter. There are different motives and they change, and the characters change. The game is short as hell, but so was the first Max Payne, and with less frustration.Max Payne 2 is a better game than the original and, for all intents and purposes, you shouldn't feel compelled to play through the first Max Payne before you play this one. It is a truly great game.

Posted: June 8, 2014
												Easily the best Max Payne in the series, almost every aspect of this game is nothing short of amazing. It improves upon the original a hell of a lot, making it feel almost like a completely different game, and it is. It's one of those games where the developers really put a lot of time and effort into all the different details, and it shows. The writing is actually really really good, with a ton of memorable quotes both dramatic and hilarious. The graphics, while dated, still don't look bad at all and show a good sense of style, especially the comic book cutscenes. Plus the ragdoll physics are just as hilarious and fun now as they were when it first came out. The voice acting, sound effects, and soundtrack are all well done, with this game showing one of the first songs to be released by Poets of the Fall. The story is dark and dramatic, yet the sense of humor through the game keeps it from being too overwhelming and even more interesting. Plus it is told in a way that both well paced and keeps the gameplay fun. A good story that is told well is pretty rare in games, especially one with as much action as this.If there are any issues with the game, 1 would be that there is in fact an escort mission. As far as escort missions go, the setup is actually pretty hilarious, but has the same annoyances most escort missions do, though at least the target is smart enough to take cover. There is also another section that blends escort mission and sniping mission, though thankfully that is far less annoying and actually does change up the gameplay in this instance. The other issue is the game is a bit repetitive. The mission variety is great, but the actual shooting gameplay throughout the entire game remains the same. You get to shoot, use slow motion or a slow motion dive... and take painkillers. There are some dream sequences but none of them really add any variety to the actual gameplay, they serve more like interactive cutscenes. Thankfully the game isn't long enough to where it ever gets boring. If you enjoy slow motion action, third person shooters, or dark stories that are told well, I highly recommend getting this game. It's suprisingly really funny yet really dramatic and engaging, and the gameplay is some of the best third person shooter action out there. One of my personal favorites, a fantastic game especially for the price these days.

												Max Payne 2 is more of the same, and that's not really a bad thing.  If you're not familiar with the game series, it's a third person shooter with bullet time effects and a noir style story.  There are slight improvements over the first game, such as being able to equip grenades / molotovs as a "secondary weapon" instead of having to switch from a gun to use them.  The graphics are much easier on the eyes too.  Probably the most novel part of MP2 is the levels where you have to work alongside or play as Max's love interest / femme fatale, Mona Sax.  It's interesting to play through the same timespan from both characters' point of view.  The story is fairly predictable, and the gunplay is fun as always.  The writers have played it safe with a formula that works (with a few tweaks), and as a result have made another solid game in the series.  Recommended.

Posted: September 10, 2014
												The Fall of Max Payne is one of those games that has pitch perfect writing. Sam Lake is a god amongst video game writers. What it comes down to is Max's inner monologues that subdue the player into escaping reality and entering the stark world of Max Payne.Taking place two years after the events of the first masterpiece, Max Payne has been reinstated into the NYPD and is on the case of a group of hitmen that dress up as a cleaning crew. Max follows their trail while uncovering a conspiracy involving the Inner Circle, corrupt politicians, and dirty cops. Mona Sax reemerges early in the game, surviving her apparent death after getting shot in the head in the first one. She's on the run from the police but works with Max as they have similar goals. The fall of Max Payne is that he falls in love with Mona Sax, he can't bring himself to turn her in or fight her; which makes the game a film noir love story (as stated on the iconic cover art).The gameplay is very similar to the first one, why fix something that isn't broken, right? But the graphics are substantially better, Max's face doesn't look like a distorted Sam Lake and the models are certainly more polyganyl. The nightmare scenes are easier but still kinda crazy. And the music, the music is SO good. I would at times just pause the game and let the music play in the menu while getting some water or pop.Outstanding9.7/10

Posted: October 11, 2015
												Max Payne 2 is more of the same, and that's not really a bad thing.  If you're not familiar with the game series, it's a third person shooter with bullet time effects and a noir style story.  There are slight improvements over the first game, such as being able to equip grenades / molotovs as a "secondary weapon" instead of having to switch from a gun to use them.  The graphics are much easier on the eyes too.  Probably the most novel part of MP2 is the levels where you have to work alongside or play as Max's love interest / femme fatale, Mona Sax.  It's interesting to play through the same timespan from both characters' point of view.  The story is fairly predictable, and the gunplay is fun as always.  The writers have played it safe with a formula that works (with a few tweaks), and as a result have made another solid game in the series.  Recommended.

Posted: September 28, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is the second game in the Max Payne trilogy developed by Remedy Entertainment, the same people behind the Alan Wake game and published by none other than Rockstar Games, makers of such games as Bully, Manhunt, L.A. Noire and the Grand Theft Auto seriesThe story continues right after Max Payne, I won't spoil anything from either the previous game or this sequel's story, however the story is action packed to the brim, just the same as Max PayneThankfully Max Payne 2 ran much better than Max Payne, however, you will need a widescreen modification for widescreen monitors, but on the whole, Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne ran much better than Max Payne, obviously Max Payne was developed much more before Max Payne 2 so it is understandableThe graphics, for what they were at the time have aged pretty well. The environments are well designed and the attention to detail is really there, and the character models too have been greatly improvedThe music and sound effects are good and the voice acting is good too. However, the game does suffer with volume level issues, sometimes the voice actors sound loud then at some points they sound low. Sometimes the cutscenes volume is good and at some points I can't hear a thing and have to riase the volume from my speakers to hear what they are saying, this is due to it being an old game so I don't blame the game per sei. Thankfully, it wasn't as bad as Max PayneThe cutscenes are told through a mixture of a form of a graphic novel and in-game custcenes and although Max Payne did suffer with the graphic novel custcenes (see Max Payne review for more details), they have been greatly improved in the sequelThe gameplay is a mixed bag. The famous bullet time is fun and will save you a lot of health as Max Payne dies easily, even on medium and easy difficulty. And the game is hard, you will die constantly, so much so, that I had to replay the game from medium difficulty to easy difficulty and still the game was hardYou will die constantly, and this is where my main complaint comes in. There is no auto save! If you get shot and die, you will reset to the latest save you or the game has done which is normally in the beginning of a chapter, so if you did not save manually (either by pressing F5 or by saving in the main menu), then expect to be teleported back to the latest save either you or the game did for you. This can be extremely annoying!However, Max Payne 2 is a fantastic sequel to the trilogy and I can't wait to play Rockstar's take in; Max Payne 3Max Payne 2 runs very well on modern systems, just be sure to download a mod that makes the game playable on widescreen monitors and you should be fine! Just be wary of the game's difficulty at some points... RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: January 27, 2016
												I played this back when it was first released but couldn't remember much about it so I decided to replay it.  It still holds up surprisingly well for being an older game.  The gunplay feels good (with better hit detection than the original Max Payne), the graphics are improved, and it seems to take itself a little more seriously by dropping all the goofy cartoon faces that Max Payne would make in the original (there's even an audio clip in the game where they kind of make fun of themselves for doing that).  The same old comic-style noir cut scenes are still here and as good as ever.  The story seemed a little less interesting this time and was more about Max chasing Mona Sax around and shooting up all kinds of baddies in the process.  There's a tag team section where Mona covers Max with a sniper rifle while he traverses a construction yard that is probably the pinnacle of the game's ingenuity.  The "All Ghillied Up" mission in Call of Duty 4 gets a lot of praise for this idea but Max Payne 2 really thought of it first even if they didn't execute it quite as stylistically.  Lots of interesting locales though and the way you defeat the final boss was a means of thinking outside the box before it was cool to make games that think outside the box.

												Max Payne 2 is so far the best Max Payne in the series: It is technolocially more advanced than the first one and it doesn't take itself as seriously as the third one. For such a low low price, I can recommend it to anyone who enjoys 3rd person shooters with strong story. The story of Max Payne 2 is nothing special: a detective who plays by his own rules and has nothing to lose has to undercover another conspiracy against him and the people of NYC.Very serious stuff but what makes this story-line bearable compared to the 3rd ones whinetastic borefest is that everything around our main characters (enemies, tv-shows and other npcs) are not taking themselfs seriously.for example: The tv-shows we see throughout the game are recapping the story in a extremely corny way and the enemies are bumbling doofuses. The gameplay is somewhat showing its age: combat usually happens withing 10 meter radius.This is partly because weapons have randomized spread but mostly because the maps are VERY small on todays standards (altough back in the PS2 era they were AMAZING).The main positive of the randomized spread is that cutscenes are something pure comical gold (for example the scene where the police-chief Bravura gets shot multible times he sometimes won't get hit once but he still gets bullet-holes in his chest)An addiditon to the absurdity of gun-fights is the early ragdoll-physics that cause bodies to fly all over the place (this is especially funny dring the "dramatic slowmo" scenes that pop up in specific parts of the game)My advice?Go to slowmo (or "bullet-time" as the game calls it) when enemies appear (preferably after they have spouted their funny dialoge), get within touching distance and start sircle strafing: nothing can survive that.This migth be a cheap tactic but so is the game: enemies are way accurate than you and there is more of 'em.Then again: you can heal yourself and use basic tactics against an enemy that mostly just runs at you.Only negative that I can really point out is that when you do the John Woo style jump, Max will stand up immediately after releasing the shoot-button (no matter how amny enemies are aiming him down) and you can't fire during the stand-up animation but this can be countered by using basic tactics.The guns that the game offers you are mostly pea-shooters but the game ie VERY generous with its ammo so it evens out in the end (exept the shotguns which all suck nards).In conclusion: This game does show it's age but it is still a solid game experience with goor replayability.It was good in 2003 and it still holds up in 2016.

												A thrilling conclusion to the events set up in Max Payne, Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is a rollercoaster ride of intrigue and murder. Sam Lake is a god of videogame writing, and it shows here as plot twists and betrayals abound and leave you wondering if it ever really was black and white.The gunplay is stellar, but special note must be given to the bullet-time and shootdodge mechanics of MP2. In MP1, you could only slow down time when you dodged, which was a good but flawed mechanic. In MP2, you can use bullettime without dodging (though shootdodge remains a viable option) and every kill you make while in the slowed timescale refills your bullettime meter a small function. If you're quick and skillful, you can keep it up for a long time.Overall, I'd recommend this game if you're a fan of noir, good storytelling, great gunplay and/or the first game.10/10 Bullets

												Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne- 1 из лучших игр от Rokstar, как мне кажется.    В те времена выпускать такой шедевр многого стоило.    Ясное дело, что люди нового поколоения не увидят всю прелесть этой игры, но мы-люди старого поколония, любящие по сей день игры 2000-2005 годов, гордимся этим, что в то время, было очень круто.    В данной части у нас есть возможность познакомиться с самими главным героем, нажав на определенный зоголовок в главном меню.    Также мы можем поиграть в разные режимы, например, "выживание на время", где будут появляться каждым разом враги, а ваша задача их убивать.    У вас есть возможность сыграть сюжетные задания на время. Когда-то давно было классно соревноватся на время с друзьями.    Но самое главное, конечно же сам сюжет, сюжет восхитителен, прекрасен, словами даже нельзя описать, насколько он мне понравился. Всего вас ожидает 3 главы, где будет пролог и по 6-7 подглав, где в каждой будет чудесные, небольшие видеоролики с хорошей озвучкой и актерской игрой, а также небольшие комиксы, где играет восхитительная музыка на заднем плане, а также присутствует озвучка. Комикс очень красиво нарисовали и детализировали его.    В данной игре нету уровней сложности, что, мне кажется, очень хорошо.    Огромное количество разного оружия.    Интересные и запоминающие личности, которые будут встречаться в ходе игры.    Красиво проработаная графика, приятно на нее смотреть.    Неплохая и грустная концовка игры с прекрасным сопровождением.    Конечно есть моменты, которые не понятны, например, куда надо стрелять, чтобы уничтожить главного "Босса".    Также, во время сюжетки, был момент, что нашему главному персонажу, попали в голову, но он остался жив, не понятно.Всем советую покупать!!    Игра заслуживает 10 из 10.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Only a clarification before all - MaxPayne, the original one from 2001 was a far superior product. Max Payne 2 recycled everything strong about it . Lacking though the doomsday gloom of the 90's occult gothic. Though often unnamed - that's what added the spice to the tragedy. Instead it attempts to portray that tragedy replayed as Max tries to overcome it.  The story of this game seems rather a rehash of the previous levels with new skins, physics, weapons and so on.What is left of Noir, is buried under the monotonous (in the bad sense of the word) interiors. Build sites, endless apartment halls, streets and only by the end some sort of a palace with many awkward and glitchy moments. The strongest sequences are the beggining one, another one with the Police HQ... and that's all I remember memorable. I never understood why Max Payne 2 was good because the romance was weak, the antagonist was a joke and... overall it's just like making Die Hard 2 after Die Hard 1.But how silly, insulting the cliffhanger comes around. What were they thinking? The game might be worth it for one playthrough to see if you enjoy the new "autumn" setting contrary to the winter "Ragnarok" of the first game.It attempts to show a relationship [Spoilers!!!]  revived  of the first game (and does so poorly in my opinion). In fact, even the ending seems like a repetition of the first game's marvelous conclusion of an epic, whereas here - it seems as if I already played this somewhere... Stereotypes and old characters are back. Yet I would prefer them to remain in the dust as they unfolded, much, much more mysteriously and enigmatically in the previous game yet again. Only for action fans.Cannot find a reason for someone to play this except if you're preparing to take head on the whole trilogy.This is the worst of the 3.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												I usually don't write reviews, much less a "not recommended" one, but this one has been eating at me a long time.  I know people generally read the first couple of lines and move on, but I wanted to do this, if only for me because I'm just another opinionated ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on the internet.Before I begin, let me clarify:Max Payne 1 was the bestMax Payne 3 was alright, but not as good as MP1also: SPOILER WARNINGSOkay, where to begin?  When I first played MP2, it was a Max Payne marathon session, so I had just finished the first game (again) and wanted to finish the second one (which I had not yet played) before I played Max Payne 3.Now, when people talk about the series, MP3 especially, they always mention how the story was mediocre especially when compared to the first two games.  Granted, it wasn't much, the lack of noire was sorely missed and when compared to the FIRST game, yes, it is particularly weak.  However, I am completely baffled when people say how good MP2's story was and how it was better than MP3.  No.  Just ... no.The flimsy story for this game (spoiler warning) is simply thus:Take every character who didn't die in the first game and kill them off.There you go.  That's it.  That's the whole 3-4 hour game right there, and the story abruptly ends when the bad guy, former "friend" Vlad who decides to kill you because they couldn't think of anybody else to do it and because he's Russian so why not, is killed.  The entire story, in a nutshell, is: "... and everybody died, the end."  If anything, this game is what paved the way for MP3 to have no connection to the first game's grim, atmosphereic noir setting simply by destroying any way to connect a third game to the first or second game.  And to anyone who wants to talk about how "gritty and noir" the story is, let me remind you that Vinnie Cogniti (or however it's spelled) puts on a ♥♥♥♥ing mascot outfit his arch rival gave him only to find out it's a bomb.  You're then tasked with saving his defenseless♥♥♥♥♥for a level so that in the next cutscene (an actual cutscene, not a graphic novel panel like in the first) he can get blown up anyway.  Whoop-dee-♥♥♥♥ing-doo.So what do you do in this game?  Well, you run around and shoot people with a screwy version of bullet-time (when you activate it, time doesn't really slow down and only does the more people you kill, so if you've got a sliver of health and want to have those extra split seconds to take out a big group, like in the first game, you're in for a surprise.) occasionally triggering a graphic novel scene like in the first game, but those only come like once a CHAPTER.  And while in first game you could watch all those bits and it would tell a semi-cohesive story, in this they only come around long enough to say "HEY LOOK, SEE?  THIS IS JUST LIKE THE FIRST GAME!  LOOK AT THI-Oop, nevermind, it's over, back to game."  That's really all the noir is in this game: a coating, something to fool you into thinking it's a noir story like in the first.  Oh, and there's the really "FUN" bit where you have to protect someone whil using a sniper rifle, because trying to keep an NPC alive from a mile away is always great.In the four or so hours it will take to beat the game, you'll get to do such things as watch cutscenes, kill guys with goofy ragdoll physics (which is actually pretty fun, don't get me wrong), go to the Ragnarok again (how original), visit the same Fun-House level three ♥♥♥♥ing times (with slightly changed layout) based on Valkyr V (see guys? this is just like the first game!) and along the way, Max will meet a variety of characters from the first game before they are subsequently killed as well as a paltry handful of new characters who get killed off to.  Oh, and if you played the first game, Mona (who got kinda killed but possibly wasn't killed or whatever) apparently survived and will be your love interest through the game until she dies at the end.  And as I said, the big bad guy is Vlad, who it turns out, in a huge case of the devs going "What things can we take from the first game and cram into here and retcon the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of, used to be in the same group as Alfred Woden, who he kills, then he kills Mona (she undied so she could re-die), then you kill him, then Max has a tiny necrophilia scene and then it just ends.  Max Payne accomplishes nothing, rescues no one, learns nothing except that people near him usually end up dead pretty fast (which I kinda thought was also part of MP1's story).  Oh, and if you thought the characters in MP3 were pretty unlikeable and had no connection to Max, then I re-invite you to play this game again and really take a good, long hard thought about it.If you hated Max Payne 3's departure from noire and the things that made the first game so incredible, you can give a big round of applause to this game right here.  After playing it, there really isn't any ground left move forward from.  The only thing a sequel could have done is go far, far away from where the first two games took place and do something "fresh" with the franchise and, basically, just find some completely new ground to tread on.So, in short, it's a functional game that goes nowhere, has no point, brings nothing new to the table and only does the "Noir" bit because it has to (and believe me, they only begrudgingly come out every now and again because it's in their contract claus) and, having never played it before, I beat it in a couple of hours in one sitting.  This game offers nothing and delivers nothing.  You're better off just playing the first game because that one actually is a good story, or if you really have to have ragdolls flopping around, get the third because of dem physics.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I played the original Max Payne years ago on the original CD version (I've never touched my Steam copy).  It was a straightforward third person shooter whose graphics weren't all that great even in its own time.  Its real strengths were its story (an offering of over-the-top noir detective grit with themes from Norse mythology) and its use of "bullet time", which took advantage of the popularity of the contemporary Matrix films.The gameplay is not much different in this sequel.  It is still a linear third-person shooter with similar graphics and the occasional surreal nightmare level.  The cutscenes look the same and it remains in the noir genre.  However, the story is not nearly as interesting and abandons the interesting thematic choices of the original.  Since that was the main strength of the original, I don't think this one is worth your time at this point.  Just move on to part 3.
