Posted: November 15, 2015
												Wow. In just 2 years Remedy was able to make a sequel that made the combat even more engaging, have the dream sequences feel even more ominous, have more depth into it's main character and have some great development in-general. The atmosphere of the world is so thick you can shoot bullets through it. This game also acts as a staple of "past generation game design" with some solutions to problems being left for you to figure it out and some non-linear paths to events of the gameplay just from the player mucking about or listening to NPCs. One moment has Payne going through an apartment complex with a couple civillians that can tag along with you, helping you out in gunfights and even giving you cover when you reach a certain point. Or you can simply shoot them right away, there's no penalty for it. As long as you have a gun in your had at the time you can shoot anyone and everyone you like. There's simple touches to the gameplay that don't do much other than making Payne look even cooler (slo-mo reloading). Another one of these is TV, yes you can just sit back (stand) and watch some telly. Being honest, I spent 10 minutes watching different things on the TV until it started repeating, damn. One of the things on the TV leads into the great and not very obvious or in your face symbolism. 2 of the recurring shows on the TV give some nice symbolism to the events of the story at the moment that you watch it, or into Payne's own mindset. Sometimes even teasing future events yet to happen. And by the last level you can watch both series finale's. It's this great dream-like state that the game has that I particularly loved and that the games use to great effect. There's some nice cameo's that, if you're paying attention, you'll notice right away as well. A few points give you control of a second character for story purposes, and it's a little weird when you discover that she has the same bullet-time abilities as Payne. Just like the last one, Max's VA is just brilliant at his lines. While everyone else is either "eergh", okay or inconsistant with  their performance. Unlike the last one the game works like a charm, with absolutely no bugs or technical problems. By the end the game's world feels just as lonely and cold as Payne is feeling from what's happened during the game, the way the story unravels is great and some moment are pretty heavy *-*. Unfortuately it doesn't have the visual scope of the original and a lot of the locations you are in are just the same places you were in the last game. There are a couple great set pieces though that allow opportunities for the level design to be more creative and one being a theme park of sorts for one of the TV shows in the game, which is mainly for the psychological themes to kick in. But that unfortunately get old by the 2nd and 3rd visit there. You should already be playing/ have finished this if you enjoyed the first one, and the ending gives some great mystery to where Max's life is going to head to next. I ONLY wish it was longer.                                                                                             9/10 :)

Posted: April 17, 2014
												While not my favorite entry in the Max Payne franchise, Max Payne 2 is still an excellent, though short game. The gameplay is inherently the same as the first title, though there are several changes to the trademark bullet time mechanic. For one thing, it can be used basically in every fight. As Max kills more enemies, time slows down even more, which also you to reload faster, in an appropriatly cinematic fashion. The visuals are also essentially the same as the first game, with the welcome addition of ragdoll physics- blowing random thugs away is much more satifying. The storytelling is again similar, with the comic book style cutscenes overlayed with Max's familiar deadpan. To me, the story is the best part of the game. It ties in closely to the original game and features many of the same characters. Without going into to much detail, there are many twists across the game's 5 to 6 hour length. The relationship between Max and Mona is especially good, though I wish the sequences where you play as her stood out a bit more, as she plays exactly the same as Max. Sam Lake's writing is solid and I would say a tad better than the first game, several of Max's quips are very poetic and the ending of the game left me thinking.All in all, I would recomend this game to any Max Payne fan, though I urge anyone to check of the first game before playing this one!

												My first memory  of Max Payne 2 is my father, in full concentration mode, getting absolutely massacred by men in balaclavas. I instantly wanted a go, and thusly my love for the franchise was born.  I died a lot, and never got past the second level. Good times!That was a long time ago, and I no longer suck at Max Payne. As much.The thing that really hits you about this game (rather like the shotgun pellets fired at Max) is the learning curve it requires. The first levels see an insomniac Max exchanging small arms fire with members of a cleaning company, but it quickly escalates into tense massacres featuring you versus the entire mafia. Don't worry, you might be ready for it!I won't ruin the storyline here, but it's bleak, absolutely beautiful and it inter-twines with the brilliant mechanics of the game well. No one can possibly dislike bullet-time diving around a corner as you dodge in between huge amounts of ordnance being flung your way by dangerously good enemies.You will die, you will get stuck. But as long as you don't mind chugging pain killers like mentos, re-loading every chance you get and aiming for the head, you'll be fine and have a great time.In my mind this game is one of Rockstar's best, darkest creations that deserves a special place in the heart of all gamers.Oh, and remember: The duel Ingrams are an absolute show stopper.Recommended for those who love to delve deep into a story and who are looking for an original experiance!

Posted: April 15, 2011
												In contrast with its previous iteration, Max Payne 2 feels like an action crime-thriller rather than the paced noir style of the original. The production values increased, which is a positive note unless you miss Sam Lake's lovely constipated look as Max's face. The story is taken to a whole new level, with more twists and turns than the writer can throw Norse Mythology references at you. Just like the previous game, I really enjoyed the little touches like the TV shows (which you should watch) and continuity checks (Captain Baseball Bat Boy, how I have missed you!). This crime-thriller/action/ psychodrama is something I would always smooch with my bloody lips if I didn’t had to clean it afterwards. On a side-note, check out Alan Wake if you can, another Remedy game with the same lead voice actor, fantastic writing, and with some quirky references to the man who gave us a late goodbye.

Posted: April 10, 2016
"In a nightmare, every choice you make is a wrong one."Max Payne 2 is a direct sequel, continuing the titular character's grim tale. Now a police detective, Max is thrust into a conspiracy involving a group of hitmen known as the "Cleaners." In the process of digging up their identity, he comes across Mona Sax, a femme fatale he assumed had been dead for two years. Making an unlikely duo, they work together to uncover dark secrets and create new ones.+The action is even better this time. The first game set the bar with its bullet time mechanics, and the sequel works to apply a fine polish. Now, during slowdown, you can quickly reload with a stylish spin, allowing you to pull of some impressive clears. All the guns handle well and the controls are precise. There wasn't a bad action sequence in this game.+Stellar plot. Max and Mona's complex relationship adds a layer of intrigue to the mystery. Given their nature--one a cop, one a criminal--the story chooses to test how far they will go to aid each other. Like all good noir stories, there is romance, betrayal, violence, and overwhelming darkness. It's a short story, but the plot is solid, an improvement from the previous title. This time to graphic novel style looks a little better in appearance, and isn't as overwhelmed with tiresome metaphors.+Attention to detail. Contrary to the last game, Max Payne 2 has some wonderful environments. Back alleys, drug dens, funhouses, police stations; it's much more varied this time. While it remains a linear game, there is plenty to explore and uncover. Every stage has television sets that you can interact with. Each features a handful of shows that will reoccur throughout the game. They are very campy in nature and tend to have parallels with Max's own situation, revealing how silly the plot can sound without the dark overtones. It's clear that the game isn't afraid to make fun of itself, and that makes the experience easy to appreciate.-Game length. It only took about five hours to beat the game. At 9.99 this is no issue. It's well worth the money. But at the same time, this game was once sold at full retail price. There are plenty of modes to replay the game with, but I'm not sure if it would have warranted a full purchase. I don't want to undersell how much I loved the game (it has to be one of the best games I've ever played), but it was almost too short. The first game had a good length, and this one was about three hours short of that. That said, nothing in the game feels like a waste of time. There is no padding to be found. Everything that occurs moves the plot along efficiently. It's unfortunate that such a good experience only lasts for such a short time, but I understand the reasoning.-Glitches. There was one level, an escort mission, that I had issues with due to a glitch. The character I was protecting would not go through a doorway, and continued to get stuck even when I restarted the mission. It took a bit of fiddling around to manage to get him through (I basically had to use the door to smash him through the doorway). This was the only part of the game I had issues with, but it did dampen my experience. Without this moment of annoyance, Max Payne 2 could've been an entirely perfect game. It's strange to witness, as the rest of the game seems technically astounding.Max Payne 2 is an incredible game. It puts most current-gen shooters to shame and has a story that is enjoyable from start to finish. The short length is a bit jarring, but the end result is a game that feels like a full experience. There is no useless filler to pad out the experience. Instead, Max Payne 2 leaves you feeling very satisfied by the end.Buy it. It's one of the best shooting games out there.

												Absolutely excellent game. Very good story, good graphics and physics (they have aged a little bit), and good game/level design. I highly recommend this game, but only if you've played Max Payne 1 (which introduced Bullet Time to video games) as the story in this game is a direct continuation. The ending is also badass, Max Payne endings are always very cool. The selection of weapons you have in this game are actually more limited in variety than in the prequel, there are no melee weapons and the M79 grenade launcher is gone from the original game. However, new weapons have been introduced to make up for this. These include the MP5, AK-47, M4 Carbine, Striker (obviously based on the real life DAO-12), and the Dragunov. Bullet Time and its role has been expanded upon. You can now reload weapons while in bullet time, via a stylish spin maneuver, and shootdodging no longer requires Adrenaline. In terms of replayability, there really isn't much. I still like to go back and replay Max Payne games sometimes, but that's just me. There is a new arcade mode called "Dead Man Walking," but all it is about is surviving for as long as possible in small maps and trying to beat your score from last time. No multiplayer unfortunately. So to reiterate, Max Payne 2 is definitely worth your time, but only if you've played Max Payne 1 and you're fine with a game with little replay value (if you're not like me).

												Max Payne 2 is a third-person action game that follows the events of Max Payne 1. It depicts a broken Max seeking redemption and he gets this through the game's other main character, a femme fatale known as Mona Sax.Story: The game is basically a tragic love story between Max Payne and Mona Sax. Over the course of the game, Mona Sax is constantly on the run (for reasons you will find out in the game) and Max Payne, now an NYPD cop must pursue her. The more Max encounters Mona, the more he becomes infatuated with her and this creates an interesting dynamic between them. The story is well-told and interesting but not as poetic and dark as the original Max Payne.Graphics: I can't say much about the graphics given that it came out more than 10 years ago (in 2003). What I can say that the visuals are still servicable and okay for today's standards and I would imagine that the graphics at the time were ground-breaking. Not so much nowadays.Gameplay: The movement, gunplay and overall responsiveness in MP2 is much improved over Max Payne 1. Now you can equip an item like a grenade to another button, instead of needing to switch to it. Bullet time is back and it feels as good as ever. It is a lot of fun to activate Bullet Time and take out 3 to 4 enemies , and this really makes you feel like a badass. There is much less frustration to the controls this time round.Overall, Max Payne 2 is a great action game that I believe has stood the test of time and is still better than some action games of today.I'd give the game an 8.5/10.

The music is great and strengthens the tension in the atmosphere, but the guns sound a little off to me. Posted: February 18, 2012
												Max Payne 2 is a triumph in third-person shooters, building strongly upon the foundation built by it's predecessor. It makes no attempt to alter the gameplay, and didn't need to- the first game's action was solid, as was its atmosphere and music, both back in full force here (including a Poets of the Fall song) But it does expand Max's story in surprising directions. A mysterious assassin, thought dead. Old friends become new enemies. The machinations of powerful men, dwelling in shadow. And in the middle of it all, Max Payne is trapped, still madly running from his past and his memories, and desiring death, finds instead a reason to live again. But Max is the consumate Noir protagonist, a survivor, cursed to emerge unscathed from the fires of his personal hell again and again. We will see how just how far he can run when Max Payne 3 releases this coming March.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												  This game is absolutely wonderful. Everything, from the graphics to the storyline, all meshes into an almost perfect experience. The gunplay is satisfying, the story is intriguing, and the level design flows you from each combat scenario to the next. The story continues from where the first one left off, and while I recommend that you play that one first, I love that Max Payne 2 can stand alone as its own story, and I personally think that the story is better than the first. Along with the story, everything else is improved. The graphics are way better (The faces are much improved), bullet time is more useful because you move the same speed as everyone else moves slower, and guns have more heft, and if you can kill enemies in one hit if you get a headshot. Overall, I think Max Payne 2 is the perfect sequel; improving everything from the original while still keeping the spirit of the first one.10/10

As much.The thing that really hits you about this game (rather like the shotgun pellets fired at Max) is the learning curve it requires. The first levels see an insomniac Max exchanging small arms fire with members of a cleaning company, but it quickly escalates into tense massacres featuring you versus the entire mafia. Don't worry, you might be ready for it!I won't ruin the storyline here, but it's bleak, absolutely beautiful and it inter-twines with the brilliant mechanics of the game well. No one can possibly dislike bullet-time diving around a corner as you dodge in between huge amounts of ordnance being flung your way by dangerously good enemies.You will die, you will get stuck. But as long as you don't mind chugging pain killers like mentos, re-loading every chance you get and aiming for the head, you'll be fine and have a great time.In my mind this game is one of Rockstar's best, darkest creations that deserves a special place in the heart of all gamers.Oh, and remember: The duel Ingrams are an absolute show stopper.Recommended for those who love to delve deep into a story and who are looking for an original experiance!

Posted: November 26, 2013
												The second entry in the Max Payne series by Remedy Games and later, Rockstar. It begins two years after the last game, with the eponymous Max Payne having left the DEA in the wake of his rampage. He is then drawn into another conspiracy, this time with a femme fatale as an ally. The gameplay is standard Max Payne-fare: shoot it up. It is an enjoyable third-person shooter, utilizing the same bullet time gimmick as the first game. The mechanic is now improved, being longer as well as more "fun". A healthy addition to the series is the implementation of Havok physics, meaning that enemies now ragdoll upon death.The game is about 8-10 hours long, depending on how much time you invest into listening to voicemails. In my opinion, it is significantly shorter than the first game. However, this should not deter you from playing this masterpiece.

												In my opinion, this is the best Max Payne game of the series, and it holds up surprisingly well given its age. Released alongside titles such as Call of Duty, Beyond Good and Evil, and Knights of the Old Republic, Max Payne 2 suffered the same issue as Psychonauts: a great game with great reviews, although nobody bought it. The gameplay and gun mechanics are only really comparable to the original Max Payne (another great game that has aged well), except they're much tighter and more refined. The infamous Bullet Time ability works quite well here, and the shoot-dodging mechanic is almost perfected. The weapons all work fairly well, although the pistols and shotguns become a little too situational to be practical at the end of the game. The story itself is fairly cut and dry, although the Noir comicbook style of storytelling gives the game it's real charm. Unlike the first Max Payne, the comicbook segments are intercut with cutscenes which serve only to enhance the overall experience. The gameplay has enough variety to remain fairly fresh through its runtime, including pseudo-escort missions which don't actually suck. The biggest criticism this game received was its short length, and, too be fair, that's not too far off the mark. In comparison to the original game, this one is certainly shorter, although this has the added benefit of substantial pacing. The environments are varied enough to be quite distinct (an attribute many modern games can't compare to), and the comparatively shorter length helps make this game an easy pill to swallow.To anyone interested in the Max Payne series (and, if you like artistic games, well crafted single player storytelling, or fine-tuned slow-mo gun battles you should be), this is the crown jewel, although this game can be best appreciated after a playthrough of the original game for context and a better understanding of how this game's engine improved significantly in two years. The third installment, Max Payne 3, is certainly fun in its own right as well, although, with so many little things changed, altered, and tweaked, it simply doesn't give as good of an appreciation of the Max Payne franchise that this game can provide.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I finally found my way to "Max Payne 3", and as preparation before the third installment, I decided to revisit the first two games to brush up on the story, get in the right mood, and simply to see if they still hold up as well as I remembered them. They do. In fact, they're even better, with me being a more mature gamer and properly appreciating the work of art that is the MP franchise. After being done with MP1, I jumped to MP2, which is also the first MP title I ever played and a such holds a special spot in my gaming heart.Is it a sequel worthy of the first game? Yes, yes it is. 100%, and then some. Basically, all that was bad in MP1 was fixed in MP2, and all that was good was made better. MP2 features even better comic book style narrations. The script is equally well-written as before. In addition, the game now has proper cutscenes which provide a good transition between some scenes.Gameplay-wise, the tempo has been balanced a bit. Instead of the relentless onslaught, there are sections in MP2 which are exploratory only. The infamous dream-like sequences have been remodeled and made far less frustrating. Bullet time has undergone a few subtle changes, all for the better. There are some graphical improvements and fancy animations, of course, but the most important one is in the gameplay mechanic. Remember how in MP1 you would shoot-dodge (that is, dive in bullet time) and if you weren't able to clear the room of enemies in that one slow-mo leap, you'd be forced to watch an animation of Max standing up, during which he'd be powerless - and most likely dead, considering MP1's punishing difficulty. Now, after shoot-dodging, Max can remain down, firing his guns from a prone position. This makes a world of difference.The game's difficulty has also been adjusted. That is not to say the game is easy. You'll still die, but nowhere nearly as often as before. Quick save is still present, but it won't be your #1 button anymore. I admit the adjusted difficulty made for a more enjoyable and fluid experience. And for those wanting an extra challenge, there are tougher difficulties to choose from once you beat the game - including unlocking and alternate ending for beating the game on the highest difficulty.And lastly, visually, for a game 11 years old, MP2 is stunning, and only the most shallow gamers would condemn it for "looking bad".MP2 is a must-play game for anyone who deems himself a lover of 3rd person shooters - or simply great games in general.

Posted: April 10, 2016
"In a nightmare, every choice you make is a wrong one."Max Payne 2 is a direct sequel, continuing the titular character's grim tale. Now a police detective, Max is thrust into a conspiracy involving a group of hitmen known as the "Cleaners." In the process of digging up their identity, he comes across Mona Sax, a femme fatale he assumed had been dead for two years. Making an unlikely duo, they work together to uncover dark secrets and create new ones.+The action is even better this time. The first game set the bar with its bullet time mechanics, and the sequel works to apply a fine polish. Now, during slowdown, you can quickly reload with a stylish spin, allowing you to pull of some impressive clears. All the guns handle well and the controls are precise. There wasn't a bad action sequence in this game.+Stellar plot. Max and Mona's complex relationship adds a layer of intrigue to the mystery. Given their nature--one a cop, one a criminal--the story chooses to test how far they will go to aid each other. Like all good noir stories, there is romance, betrayal, violence, and overwhelming darkness. It's a short story, but the plot is solid, an improvement from the previous title. This time to graphic novel style looks a little better in appearance, and isn't as overwhelmed with tiresome metaphors.+Attention to detail. Contrary to the last game, Max Payne 2 has some wonderful environments. Back alleys, drug dens, funhouses, police stations; it's much more varied this time. While it remains a linear game, there is plenty to explore and uncover. Every stage has television sets that you can interact with. Each features a handful of shows that will reoccur throughout the game. They are very campy in nature and tend to have parallels with Max's own situation, revealing how silly the plot can sound without the dark overtones. It's clear that the game isn't afraid to make fun of itself, and that makes the experience easy to appreciate.-Game length. It only took about five hours to beat the game. At 9.99 this is no issue. It's well worth the money. But at the same time, this game was once sold at full retail price. There are plenty of modes to replay the game with, but I'm not sure if it would have warranted a full purchase. I don't want to undersell how much I loved the game (it has to be one of the best games I've ever played), but it was almost too short. The first game had a good length, and this one was about three hours short of that. That said, nothing in the game feels like a waste of time. There is no padding to be found. Everything that occurs moves the plot along efficiently. It's unfortunate that such a good experience only lasts for such a short time, but I understand the reasoning.-Glitches. There was one level, an escort mission, that I had issues with due to a glitch. The character I was protecting would not go through a doorway, and continued to get stuck even when I restarted the mission. It took a bit of fiddling around to manage to get him through (I basically had to use the door to smash him through the doorway). This was the only part of the game I had issues with, but it did dampen my experience. Without this moment of annoyance, Max Payne 2 could've been an entirely perfect game. It's strange to witness, as the rest of the game seems technically astounding.Max Payne 2 is an incredible game. It puts most current-gen shooters to shame and has a story that is enjoyable from start to finish. The short length is a bit jarring, but the end result is a game that feels like a full experience. There is no useless filler to pad out the experience. Instead, Max Payne 2 leaves you feeling very satisfied by the end.Buy it. It's one of the best shooting games out there.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Just two years after the first Max Payne (2001) was released, Remedy came up with their second creation of the series, Max Payne 2 (2003). This time they developed a game which had a whole lot of better graphics, upgraded game mechanics, more interesting level design, a bunch of new guns and an enhanced level of voice acting as well as an enhancend level of enemy AI. Anyhow, like it's predecessor, Max Payne 2 is also quite a fast-paced game. The guns introduced in the game have a good feel on them and while bullet time or shoot dodge is being used at the same time, it will double the enjoyment. Also, the enemies are not able to take ridiculous amount of bullets before they die anymore, which is a huge improvement on its own over the first Max Payne game. The gradually slowing bullet time is an awesome invention as it is easier for the player to handle big amount of opponents at the same time. The controllabilty of Max's moves is still going strong, the level of voice acting is great and because there is some improvements on the enemy AI, Max Payne 2 is a very enjoyable game at its best.Now, not only the game mechanics has been proven to be better in Max Payne 2 than they are in Max Payne 1, but also the graphics have taken a big leap forward. Overall the environmental texturing have gotten to a higher level. Max can see his own reflection and the faces seen in the game are more natural than they used to be in the previous Max Payne game. The cars are a bit more than just boxes on the wheels and the whole level design is much more interesting.Despite all the enhancements, the game is still all about running and shooting with no considerable variation between the firefights you encounter. The overall amount of usable guns is still quite low and the game will not last too long, as an average person who is playing the game through for the first time can beat the game in about 5 hours. Additional game modes seem to be quite useless to try as there is nothing to achieve by playing them. Also the original dark and gritty story has been swapped to a new and lame one, which is all about Max losing another loved one while also being betrayed by someone thought to be a friend of his. The dreams Max is experiencing while the story goes on have lost a big part of their original meaning as a source of dark and twisted feelings.After all there is a huge amount of improvements in Max Payne 2, even though the run and shoot part leaves still much to be desired along with some other downsides seen in the game. Throughout the game you can find some easter eggs, and the mods made for this game can offer you a lot of additional fun. To this date I have beaten Max Payne 2 six times: three times before I had it on Steam and three times after that, with every given difficulty option. Because the game is quite short, I ended up spending only about 30 hours by playing it and could still give it a go. In other words I don't regret the time I have spent playing on this game. If you liked the predecessor of Max Payne 2, without a doubt you will fall in love with this one. The quality has been guaranteed, even though some things mentioned above could have been made better.

												There are few games that I'd say they are a master of their genre. May Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne is definitely one of them. I'd say it's the last of the good old games. Max Payne 2 is a strange specimen because it's between two periods, the old and the new. It has the charm of oldschool games while feeling modern and polished. The action is one of the best I've ever seen. The gameplay feels very cinematic, inspired by John Woo's motion pictures. But the best thing they've introduced since the first Max Payne is the physics engine. Enemies fall spectacularly when they die, especially in slow motion, and you can even jump into them and drive them to the floor.The visual novel style cutscenes are back from the first game along with the heavy noir atmosphere. This time I fell like they've put a bit more emphasis on the detective aspects of the story which I personally love, and it's still every bit as thrilling as the first game (if not more). The music is great and strengthens the tension in the atmosphere, but the guns sound a little off to me. The main problem with the game is that it's too short in my opinion, but with the challenge modes making a return, and given the exquisite gameplay, I think you'll find yourself playing this game over and over again.I can't recommend this enough. Go buy it! 10/10

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Max Payne 2 is a third-person action game that follows the events of Max Payne 1. It depicts a broken Max seeking redemption and he gets this through the game's other main character, a femme fatale known as Mona Sax.Story: The game is basically a tragic love story between Max Payne and Mona Sax. Over the course of the game, Mona Sax is constantly on the run (for reasons you will find out in the game) and Max Payne, now an NYPD cop must pursue her. The more Max encounters Mona, the more he becomes infatuated with her and this creates an interesting dynamic between them. The story is well-told and interesting but not as poetic and dark as the original Max Payne.Graphics: I can't say much about the graphics given that it came out more than 10 years ago (in 2003). What I can say that the visuals are still servicable and okay for today's standards and I would imagine that the graphics at the time were ground-breaking. Not so much nowadays.Gameplay: The movement, gunplay and overall responsiveness in MP2 is much improved over Max Payne 1. Now you can equip an item like a grenade to another button, instead of needing to switch to it. Bullet time is back and it feels as good as ever. It is a lot of fun to activate Bullet Time and take out 3 to 4 enemies , and this really makes you feel like a badass. There is much less frustration to the controls this time round.Overall, Max Payne 2 is a great action game that I believe has stood the test of time and is still better than some action games of today.I'd give the game an 8.5/10.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												In my opinion this game is in most aspects an improvement over the original. But be warned: Steam version is as bad as Max Payne 1. If you have an OS that is newer than Windows XP, you will need to find and install some fixes for the game to even run, and then some more to fix the sounds issues and give it proper widescreen support.After you get it up and running properly, expect the following:- This game is much, much easier than the original Max Payne. Probably not too easy, but at least you will suffer much less cheap deaths, especially instant ones. Aiming is still hindered by forced vSync, but feels significantly more fluid than in previous game. There are harder modes for more challenge, but you need to beat it on default difficulty first.- Combat feels less luck-based and more dependent on player's actual skill. Enemies, however, are not as mobile as in MP1, but still move around quite a bit. Weapons are rebalanced and are more diverse and shooting feels, for a lack of better term, just better. However, in most situations the player is stocked with enormous amount of weapons and ammo, which is nice from the variety perspective, but it also means that there is only a handful of instances where ammo conservation is a thing. The boss battle is also much more interesting.- Physics are improved and expanded. There is semi-decent ragdoll in place now, and there's a lot of reactive clutter all over the levels, which adds quite a bit to the spectacle, especially when there are explosions going off. Speaking of spectacle - it looks just phenomenal for its age. Only human models are somewhat sub-par, but still huge improvement over the original.- There is a metric ton of side content - TV shows, conversations, environmental storytelling, and thankfully you can skip it all very easily.- The tone is entirely different now. MP1 was gritty, its humor was dark. MP2 is still a blood-soaked tragedy, but much lighter and cheesier, shifting from noir to alsmot being kitsch. It is both serious and deconstructive at the same time, hard-hitting the player with tangible drama, and then outright mocking events that predated the sequel - just watch a couple of 'episodes' of♥♥♥♥♥♥Justice on MP2's TVs. MP1 was suffering of both character and player, and MP2 leaves the pain to Payne(see what I did there?). But despite being somewhat bipolar, it delivers the 'feels' when it has the intent to do so.- Bullet time is revamped. It regenerates now and is easier to use. Whether you'll like it or not is up to a personal preference.If you enjoy story-rich third-person shooters this is one of the better ones. Buy it and play it. Just maybe try to buy it elsewhere first.
